name: Djinguereber Mosque
description: Built in 1327 by Mansa Musa, this is the oldest of Timbuktu’s three famous mud-brick mosques that formed the University of Timbuktu. UNESCO World Heritage site.

name: Sankoré Mosque (Madrasah)
description: 14th–15th century center of Islamic learning, part of the University of Timbuktu; later restored to Kaaba-like dimensions by Imam al-Aqib. UNESCO World Heritage site.

name: Sidi Yahya Mosque
description: Completed in 1440 and named for its first imam. Part of the University of Timbuktu; heavily damaged in 2012 but restored by UNESCO.

name: Ahmed Baba Institute (IHERI-AB)
description: Founded 1973 and rebuilt in 2009, this modern archive protects over 20,000 ancient manuscripts using climate-controlled preservation.

name: Mamma Haidara Commemorative Library
description: Private villa housing ~22,000 manuscripts, preserved by the Haidara family across generations.

name: Fundo Kati (Kati Manuscript Library)
description: Private family library preserving Songhai chronicles like Tarikh al-Fettash, part of Timbuktu’s rich scholarly heritage.

name: Old-Town Historic Center
description: Wander sun-baked, sand-filled streets of adobe homes and courtyards—a living, tactile history experience.

name: Sahara Camel Ride / Local Festival Experience
address: Sahara Desert or festival site near Timbuktu, e.g., Essakane (~70 km away)
description: Saddle up for sunset camel rides on the dunes or immerse yourself in Tuareg-led cultural festivals—an adventure into desert magic.
